Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the 40 percent statistic is based on a study conducted before background checks were required.
Understate: The claim understates the significance of the 40 percent statistic by labeling it as a "highly dubious figure."
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to fully discredit the 40 percent statistic, as it only mentions that it is based on a study conducted before background checks were required.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the 40 percent statistic is unreliable solely because it was gathered before background checks were required, without considering other factors that may affect its validity.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim implies that the 40 percent statistic is due to purchases from private individuals, without considering other potential reasons for the lack of background checks.
